Simstock API docs

The SimstockDataframe class

class simstock.SimstockDataframe(inputobject: Any, polygon_column_name: str = None, uid_column_name: str = None, epw_file: str = None, tol: float = 0.1, use_base_idf: str = False, **kwargs)

Bases: object

A SimstockDataframe is an object used by simstock to represent all input data. It behaves the in the same way as a Pandas data frame, but with some key additional methods to perform geometric-based pre-processing.

In order to be a valid SimstockDataframe, there must be one column names polygon that contains geometric data.

Additional required column names are: - osgb - shading - height - nofloors - construction - interiors

:param data : Any: The polygon data together with osgb data etc. :param index : array-like or Index: The index for the SimstockSeries. :param tol : float: The tolerance to apply when assessing polygon intersections. :param Usage example: :param ————-: :param ```python: :param import simstock as sim: :param sdf = sim.read_csv(“text.csv”): :param # Access data in the smae way as a pandas dataframe: :param print(sdf.columns): :param >>> Index([‘polygon’: ‘construction’, ‘interiors’],

dtype=’object’)

Parameters:

  • 'osgb' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'shading' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'height' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'wwr' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'nofloors' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

:param‘construction’, ‘interiors’],

dtype=’object’)

Parameters:

  • print(sdf.loc[sdf["osgb"]=="osgb1000005307038" –

  • "polygon"]) –

  • 186137 (>>> POLYGON ((528883.55) –

  • 186145.5... (528878.05) –

  • Name (polygon, dtype: object) –

  • preprocessing (# Perform) –

  • sdf.preprocessing() –

  • ``` –

``is_ccw : bool or list<bool>``

Are the geometries counter-clockwise.

``is_exterior_ccw : bool or list<bool>``

Are the exterior perimeters counter-clockwise.

``is_valid : bool or list<bool>``

Are the geometries valid objects.

``length : int``

The length of the data (axis=0).

bi_adj() → None
property building: list
collinear_exterior(**kwargs) → None

Function that removes collinear points from polygons and determines exterior surfaces.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

common_posix_paths = ['/usr/local/EnergyPlus*/Energy+.idd', '/Applications/EnergyPlus*/Energy+.idd']
common_windows_paths = ['C:\\EnergyPlus*\\Energy+.idd']
property constructions: list
create_csv_folder(dirname: str = 'simulation_settings') → None
property electric_equipment: list
property global_geometry_rules: list
property heat_balance_algorith: list
idd_file = None
property infiltration: list
property inside_convection_algorith: list
property is_ccw: list[bool]

property : list[bool] Are the polygon column objects counter-clockwise?

property is_exterior_ccw: list[bool]

property : list[bool] Do the polygon column objects have counter-clockwise exteriors?

property is_valid: list[bool]

property : list[bool] Are the polygon column objects valid shapley objects?

property length: int

property : int The length of the columns in the dataframe.

property lights: list
property material_nomass: list
property materials: list
orientate_polygons(**kwargs) → None

Function to ensure that polygon exteriors and interiors are correctly orientated clockwise/anti-clockwise.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

property output_diagnostics: list
property output_variable: list
property output_variable_dictionaryt: list
property outside_convection_algorith: list
override_settings_with_csv(**kwargs) → None
property people: list
polygon_simplification(**kwargs) → None

Function that simplifies polygons, by e.g. exploiting transitivity of points and merging points within tolerances.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

polygon_tolerance(**kwargs) → None

A function to assess which polygons need simplifying, based on a user-specifed tolerance. This can be set via tol in kwargs. Simplification here means removing intermediate coordinates in a shape while preserving the shapes topology. Coordinates that are closer together than some tolerance are candidates for removal.

This function adds a boolean column named simplify which specifies whether each polygon needs simplifying or not, based on the tolerance.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments. :param Usage example: :param ————-: :param `python: :param sdf.polygon_toerance(tol=0.1): :param `:

polygon_topology(**kwargs) → None

Function that checks whether polygons are touching or interecting each other. If any intersections are detected, an error is thrown.

This function adds an additonal column to the SimstockDataframe called touching. The i^th entry in touching lists the osbg values of all polygons touching the polygon in row i.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If any polygons are touching.

  • Usage –

  • ----- –

  • ``pytho –

  • import simstock as sim –

  • sdf = sim.read_csv("path/to/file.csv") –

  • sdf.polygon_topology() –

  • ` –

preprocessing(**kwargs) → None

Function to perform default processing on the SimstockDataframe to ready it for IDF creation.

This function first checks that all polygons are correctly orientated. It then proceeds to remove duplicate coordinates and simplify polygons while ensuring that polygons do not intersect each other.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

Raises:

ValueError – If polygons cannot be simplified without causing intersection.

print_settings() → None
remove_duplicate_coords(**kwargs) → None

Function to remove duplicated coordinates from polygons, while ensuring the polygons remain valid shapely objects.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments. :param Usage: :param —–: :param `python: :param import simstock as sim: :param sdf = sim.read_csv("path/to/file.csv"): :param sdf.remove_duplicate_coords(): :param `:

required_cols = ['shading', 'height', 'wwr', 'nofloors', 'construction']

Submodules

simstock.base module

Module containing the base simstock objects: - SimstockDataframe - IDFcreator

class simstock.base.IDFmanager(data: Any, **kwargs)

Bases: object

An IDFmanager is a container object used to create elements for an EnergyPlus simulation. The object contains functions to take geometric and contextual data in the form of a SimstockDataframe, and create an IDF file or Eppy IDF object for an E+ run.

:param data : dict-like: Data containing polygon and contextual information. :param idf : IDF: The IDF object containing elements for E+. :param idd_file : str = None: The path to the idd_file on the user’s computer.

If none is given, the initialiser function will attempt to find one autmatically.

:param ep_basic_settings : str = None: The path to the idf file containing the basic settings

for E+. If none is given, then the system reverts to the basic_settings.idf.

:param min_avail_width_for_windows : float | int = 1: Windows will not be placed is wall widths are less

than this distance in metres.

:param min_avail_height : float | int = 80: Windows wil not be placed if partially exposed

external wall is less than this number % of zone height.

Parameters:

  • example (Usage) –

  • ------------- –

  • ```python –

  • sim (import simtock as) –

  • sdf (# Assuming the user has a SimstockData frame named) –

:param : :param # instantiate new IDFcreator object: :param ob = sim.IDFcreator(sdf): :param # Create all necessary E+ objects: :param # First: :param move all objects towards origin: :param ob.move_towards_origin(): :param # Create shading objects: :param ob.create_shading_objects(): :param # Create thermal zones based on floor number: :param ob.create_thermal_zones(): :param # Compute ideal load systems: :param ob.create_load_systems(): :param # All relevant data for an E+ run have now been created: :param # The results can be saved to a file: :param : :param # Or kept as an eppy idf object for further processing: :param idf = ob.idf: :param ```:

``is_valid : bool``

Are all of the necessary column names present in the input data.

``missing_columns : list[str]``

List of the names of necessary columns that are not present in the input data.

See also

SimstockDataframe

bi_mode = True
buffer_radius = 50
col_names = ['polygon', 'osgb', 'shading', 'height', 'wwr', 'nofloors', 'construction', 'interiors', 'touching', 'polygon_exposed_wall', 'polygon_horizontal']

Necessary column names that are missing from the data

out_dir = 'outs'
run(**kwargs) → None

save_idfs(**kwargs) → None
class simstock.base.SimstockDataframe(inputobject: Any, polygon_column_name: str = None, uid_column_name: str = None, epw_file: str = None, tol: float = 0.1, use_base_idf: str = False, **kwargs)

simstock.io module

IO module containing routines to read and write to various file types. Currently supported:

  • csv

  • parquet

  • geopackage

  • json

simstock.io.get_gpkg_layer_names(path: str) → list
simstock.io.read_csv(path: str, **kwargs) → SimstockDataframe

Function to read in a csv file and return a SimstockDataframe, i.e. it must contain a ``polygon column or key or field containing shapely geometry data or similar.

Parameters:

  • ``path –

    str``: The file path including the csv file

  • ``kwargs –

    dict``: optional keyword argumetns to be passed to the SimstockDataframe initialiser. See SimstockDataframe docs for details of allowed arguments.

Returns:

See SimstockDataframe docs for full list of attributes and methods.

Return type:

sdf: SimstockDataframe

Raises:

  • TypeError –

  • If csv file does not conform to Simstock standards. –

  • Dictionary of key-words arguments to be passed to the SimstockDataframe –

  • constructor. See Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word –

  • arguments. –

Example

`python import simstock as sim sdf = sim.read_csv("/pathtofile/examplefile.csv") `

simstock.io.read_geopackage_layer(path: str, layer_name: str, **kwargs) → SimstockDataframe

Read a layer from a GeoPackage file as a pandas DataFrame using only sqlite3 and pandas.

Parameters:

  • path (str) – The path to the GeoPackage file.

  • layer_name (str) – The name of the layer to read from the GeoPackage.

Returns:

SimstockDataframe

SimstockDataframe initialiser. See SimstockDataframe docs for details of allowed arguments.

Return type:

  • arguments. –

simstock.io.to_csv(sdf: SimstockDataframe, path: str, **kwargs) → None

Function to save a SimstockDataframe object to a csv file

:param sdf : SimstockDataframe: The simstock dataframe to save. :param path : str: The file path to save to. :param kwargs : dict: optional keyword argumetns to be passed to the

SimstockDataframe initialiser. See SimstockDataframe docs for details of allowed arguments.

Example

`python sim.to_csv(sdf, "/pathtofile/examplefile.csv") `

Example

`python sim.to_csv(sdf, "/pathtofile/examplefile.json") `

Function to save a SimstockDataframe object to a parquet file

Example

`python sim.to_csv(sdf, "/pathtofile/examplefile.parquet") `

simstock.plotting module

Plotting module containing routines for plotting basic geometries.

simstock.plotting.plot(sdf: SimstockDataframe | Series | DataFrame, edgecolor: str = 'k', **kwargs) → Axes

Plot a SimstockDataframe’s geometric data.

:param sdf : SimstockDataframe or Pandas Series or Dataframe: The data to be plotted. One column must be called

polygon and contain shapely geometries.

Parameters:

  • ``**kwargs –

    All additional keyword arguments to be passed to matplotlib

  • optional`` – All additional keyword arguments to be passed to matplotlib

Returns:

Matplotlib axis object instance containing the plotted geometric data

Return type:

ax : matplotlib Axes

Examples

### Basic usage

```python import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import simstock as sim

# Create test simstockdataframe sdf = sim.read_csv(“testdata.csv”)

# Plot sim.plot(sdf, facecolor=”lightblue”, edgecolor=”red”) plt.show() ```

### More advanced usage

```python import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import simstock as sim

# Create test simstockdataframe sdf = sim.read_csv(“testdata.csv”)

# Create matplotlib figure and axis fig = plt.figure() ax = fig.add_subplot(111)

# Plot to the existing axis sim.plot(

sdf, facecolor=”lightblue”, edgecolor=”red”, ax=ax)

# Set some ttributes ax.title(“Test Plot”) ax.set_xticks([]) ax.set_yticks([])

# Display plot plt.show() ```

Module contents

class simstock.IDFmanager(data: Any, **kwargs)

Bases: object

An IDFmanager is a container object used to create elements for an EnergyPlus simulation. The object contains functions to take geometric and contextual data in the form of a SimstockDataframe, and create an IDF file or Eppy IDF object for an E+ run.

:param data : dict-like: Data containing polygon and contextual information. :param idf : IDF: The IDF object containing elements for E+. :param idd_file : str = None: The path to the idd_file on the user’s computer.

If none is given, the initialiser function will attempt to find one autmatically.

:param ep_basic_settings : str = None: The path to the idf file containing the basic settings

for E+. If none is given, then the system reverts to the basic_settings.idf.

:param min_avail_width_for_windows : float | int = 1: Windows will not be placed is wall widths are less

than this distance in metres.

:param min_avail_height : float | int = 80: Windows wil not be placed if partially exposed

external wall is less than this number % of zone height.

Parameters:

  • example (Usage) –

  • ------------- –

  • ```python –

  • sim (import simtock as) –

  • sdf (# Assuming the user has a SimstockData frame named) –

:param : :param # instantiate new IDFcreator object: :param ob = sim.IDFcreator(sdf): :param # Create all necessary E+ objects: :param # First: :param move all objects towards origin: :param ob.move_towards_origin(): :param # Create shading objects: :param ob.create_shading_objects(): :param # Create thermal zones based on floor number: :param ob.create_thermal_zones(): :param # Compute ideal load systems: :param ob.create_load_systems(): :param # All relevant data for an E+ run have now been created: :param # The results can be saved to a file: :param : :param # Or kept as an eppy idf object for further processing: :param idf = ob.idf: :param ```:

``is_valid : bool``

Are all of the necessary column names present in the input data.

``missing_columns : list[str]``

List of the names of necessary columns that are not present in the input data.

run(**kwargs) → None

save_idfs(**kwargs) → None
class simstock.SimstockDataframe(inputobject: Any, polygon_column_name: str = None, uid_column_name: str = None, epw_file: str = None, tol: float = 0.1, use_base_idf: str = False, **kwargs)

Bases: object

A SimstockDataframe is an object used by simstock to represent all input data. It behaves the in the same way as a Pandas data frame, but with some key additional methods to perform geometric-based pre-processing.

In order to be a valid SimstockDataframe, there must be one column names polygon that contains geometric data.

Additional required column names are: - osgb - shading - height - nofloors - construction - interiors

:param data : Any: The polygon data together with osgb data etc. :param index : array-like or Index: The index for the SimstockSeries. :param tol : float: The tolerance to apply when assessing polygon intersections. :param Usage example: :param ————-: :param ```python: :param import simstock as sim: :param sdf = sim.read_csv(“text.csv”): :param # Access data in the smae way as a pandas dataframe: :param print(sdf.columns): :param >>> Index([‘polygon’: ‘construction’, ‘interiors’],

dtype=’object’)

Parameters:

  • 'osgb' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'shading' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'height' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'wwr' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

  • 'nofloors' – ‘construction’, ‘interiors’], dtype=’object’)

:param‘construction’, ‘interiors’],

dtype=’object’)

Parameters:

  • print(sdf.loc[sdf["osgb"]=="osgb1000005307038" –

  • "polygon"]) –

  • 186137 (>>> POLYGON ((528883.55) –

  • 186145.5... (528878.05) –

  • Name (polygon, dtype: object) –

  • preprocessing (# Perform) –

  • sdf.preprocessing() –

  • ``` –

polygon_simplification(**kwargs) → None

Function that simplifies polygons, by e.g. exploiting transitivity of points and merging points within tolerances.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

polygon_tolerance(**kwargs) → None

A function to assess which polygons need simplifying, based on a user-specifed tolerance. This can be set via tol in kwargs. Simplification here means removing intermediate coordinates in a shape while preserving the shapes topology. Coordinates that are closer together than some tolerance are candidates for removal.

This function adds a boolean column named simplify which specifies whether each polygon needs simplifying or not, based on the tolerance.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments. :param Usage example: :param ————-: :param `python: :param sdf.polygon_toerance(tol=0.1): :param `:

polygon_topology(**kwargs) → None

Function that checks whether polygons are touching or interecting each other. If any intersections are detected, an error is thrown.

This function adds an additonal column to the SimstockDataframe called touching. The i^th entry in touching lists the osbg values of all polygons touching the polygon in row i.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If any polygons are touching.

  • Usage –

  • ----- –

  • ``pytho –

  • import simstock as sim –

  • sdf = sim.read_csv("path/to/file.csv") –

  • sdf.polygon_topology() –

  • ` –

preprocessing(**kwargs) → None

Function to perform default processing on the SimstockDataframe to ready it for IDF creation.

This function first checks that all polygons are correctly orientated. It then proceeds to remove duplicate coordinates and simplify polygons while ensuring that polygons do not intersect each other.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments.

Raises:

ValueError – If polygons cannot be simplified without causing intersection.

print_settings() → None
remove_duplicate_coords(**kwargs) → None

Function to remove duplicated coordinates from polygons, while ensuring the polygons remain valid shapely objects.

:param kwargs : dict: Dictionary of key-words arguments, see Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word arguments. :param Usage: :param —–: :param `python: :param import simstock as sim: :param sdf = sim.read_csv("path/to/file.csv"): :param sdf.remove_duplicate_coords(): :param `:

simstock.plot(sdf: SimstockDataframe | Series | DataFrame, edgecolor: str = 'k', **kwargs) → Axes

Plot a SimstockDataframe’s geometric data.

:param sdf : SimstockDataframe or Pandas Series or Dataframe: The data to be plotted. One column must be called

polygon and contain shapely geometries.

Parameters:

  • ``**kwargs –

    All additional keyword arguments to be passed to matplotlib

  • optional`` – All additional keyword arguments to be passed to matplotlib

Returns:

Matplotlib axis object instance containing the plotted geometric data

Return type:

ax : matplotlib Axes

Examples

### Basic usage

```python import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import simstock as sim

# Create test simstockdataframe sdf = sim.read_csv(“testdata.csv”)

# Plot sim.plot(sdf, facecolor=”lightblue”, edgecolor=”red”) plt.show() ```

### More advanced usage

```python import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import simstock as sim

# Create test simstockdataframe sdf = sim.read_csv(“testdata.csv”)

# Create matplotlib figure and axis fig = plt.figure() ax = fig.add_subplot(111)

# Plot to the existing axis sim.plot(

sdf, facecolor=”lightblue”, edgecolor=”red”, ax=ax)

# Set some ttributes ax.title(“Test Plot”) ax.set_xticks([]) ax.set_yticks([])

# Display plot plt.show() ```

simstock.read_csv(path: str, **kwargs) → SimstockDataframe

Function to read in a csv file and return a SimstockDataframe, i.e. it must contain a ``polygon column or key or field containing shapely geometry data or similar.

Parameters:

  • ``path –

    str``: The file path including the csv file

  • ``kwargs –

    dict``: optional keyword argumetns to be passed to the SimstockDataframe initialiser. See SimstockDataframe docs for details of allowed arguments.

Returns:

See SimstockDataframe docs for full list of attributes and methods.

Return type:

sdf: SimstockDataframe

Raises:

  • TypeError –

  • If csv file does not conform to Simstock standards. –

  • Dictionary of key-words arguments to be passed to the SimstockDataframe –

  • constructor. See Simstockbase for full list of recognised key word –

  • arguments. –

Example

`python import simstock as sim sdf = sim.read_csv("/pathtofile/examplefile.csv") `
